title: Dramatic response to selective internal radiation therapy for unresectable hepatocellular carcinoma
patient: A 54-year-old woman with a known history of multifocal hepatocellular carcinoma was treated with initial right partial hepatectomy and subsequently transhepatic arterial chemoembolization (TACE) for recurrent unresectable disease 12 months after surgery. Five months post TACE, she developed worsening abdominal discomfort, and fluorodeoxyglucose positron emission tomography with computed tomography (FDG-PET/CT) scan showed evidence of progressive disease with increased FDG uptake in lesions involving segments 2, 3, 7 and 8 (Fig. a). She was treated with selective internal radiation therapy (SIRT) using yttrium-90 (90Y) microspheres (SIR-Spheres®), which were infused into left, middle and right hepatic arteries (Fig. a). At 9-week follow-up, her abdominal discomfort had resolved and FDG-PET/CT scan demonstrated a near complete metabolic response (Fig. b). Subsequent angiography revealed parasitized arterial supply to the segment 7 tumour from the inferior phrenic artery, which would explain the inadequate perfusion and dose delivery of 90Y microspheres (Fig. a, cross-hairs) with only a partial response of the single lesion (Fig. b, cross-hairs).
